segments.text: This is the second interview with General Becker.
Today is July 2nd, 1981, and last time we were talking about, I think we finished a conversation on the Philippines.
Is that true?
Well, we got into the invasion of the Philippines.
Yeah, we were talking about that.
We could wind that up by briefly concluding the campaign in the Philippines.
We haven't done that.
Of course, my entire World War II experience was with the 1st Cavalry Division, which had been organized, reorganized really as a light infantry division.
And from that invasion of the Lady Islands, the division went on up to Luzon, the major island, you know.
Right.
And some of our proudest accomplishments resulted from that operation.
We went into after the invasion of Luzon by other forces.
And General Walsh Kruger, the 6th Army Commander, gave the first count on the mission to proceed through all other units straight to Manila, which was 300 kilometers away.
to seize the seat of government, the Malacanon Palace.
Our first objective was to liberate the prisoners at Santa Tomas University.
And the division was provided tanks and trucks to put everybody on wheels or tracks and just set go.
In three days we were there and those missions were accomplished.
In three days you went 300 kilometers?
Yeah.
How was the fighting?
Well, it was only very light because we just completely surprised the enemy.
It was very light until we'd actually seized the objective.
Of course, there were some small battles along the way.
But it was very successful because of the element of surprise and speed of the
And they'd never seen anything like that, of course, in the war, in the jungles.
Well, of course, in Luzon, you had a fairly decent road net, and this was possible.
And then, of course, the laborious process of cleaning the enemy out of Manila followed, because as time went on, of course, they step in there, resolve in resistance, and it took some months.
to get that job done before we aimed at invasion of Japan, which will come later I'm guessing here, which thankfully never occurred.
Right.
In the Philippines, the Japanese had a General Yamashita, who was a so-called Tiger of Manila, and he was the first man after the Second World War to be
to be found guilty of war crimes and then executed.
You were right there on the scene and of course this caused a flap early in 1946 and it has since.
You were right there on the scene.
How did the Jap- how did the Japanese soldiers behave?
Were they committing war crimes in your opinion?
Well I think this
evidence used against Jim Ashita related to the initial battle of the Philippines.
In which our troops at Corregidor Baton in the Philippines surrendered to the Japanese and then were so badly mistreated from then to the end of the war.
But the death march, for example, occurred then.
But to answer your question, I have no, I did not witness, of course, I wouldn't witness directly any Japanese atrocities.
I think we saw evidence of atrocities.
For example?
Well.
The Filipinos, of course, they were supposed to be.
Yeah, it's that sort of thing, it's a surmise because you don't see it.
But when you see mutilations, for example, of certain types.
There were bodies mutilated along the road when you were going to Manila?
At times.
You'd see this in different areas.
Now, it's a gruesome thing to get into, but was the person dead before or after?
But I think the thing we all recognized was that the individual Japanese soldier was a very good fighting soldier.
I think as you got up to their larger units, they were less a match for our corresponding units.
But the one thing that made the Japanese soldier so effective was that he was trained and conditioned and motivated to fight to the death.
And given that conviction, he'll do anything until he's killed.
And very few of them didn't have the courage to do that, you know, fight to the death.
More so than Americans?
Well, we at least didn't teach that philosophy.
But I don't think you'll find any more courageous soldiers anywhere than the American soldiers.
I think our particulates as larger units, but even on the small unit level,

our tactics were so superior to the Japanese that the fact was we usually won our battles and our soldiers were very seldom found in such desperate situations that they'd ever have to make a choice like that well you said before we didn't teach that philosophy toward well the philosophy taught the Japanese fight to the death or do yourself in what did we teach
Well, I think we concentrated on preparing soldiers for battle and certainly any soldier, particularly the doughboy, whose job is to close with the enemy and seize critical terrain, recognizes that
You don't have to tell him he'll fight to the death.
He knows that he'll go to the objective, whatever is required.
He is committed to the objective.
Now, no commander is going to waste life intentionally.
He's not going to get people in a situation where the casualties are going to be unexpected or unreasonable.
But you can't define those things in any given situation.

to the finite point but I think there's no apology to be made for the American soldier in any war that I've no I just wanted a difference between the two his individual courage to do whatever is necessary to the death what were the conditions when he got to Manila when we got to Manila of course it was intact
run down some because the economy had been affected so much.

The General MacArthur's orders were that we would not use artillery or bombing within the city unless it was an absolutely essential thing and then our headquarters would help decide that because he wanted to
retake the city without serious damage and devastation.
But of course, that didn't work because the Japanese just started systematically demolishing the areas in the areas in which they retained control until they were pushed out.
So in the end, the city was pretty badly destroyed, parts of it were.
And some parts we had to lift that policy, of course.
So both sides contributed to destruction in the areas which we had to fight.
Were the Filipinos happy to see you coming?
Oh, they certainly were.
They certainly were.
I guess, you know, our troops having come through so many hundreds and hundreds of miles of jungles to get there and to see that reaction, even in Leyte, in that initial invasion of the Philippines,

uh kind of made you realize better what what you were fighting for you know it was a boost to the troops it really was of course a tremendous boost to the people of the Philippines when they realized that we were back were there other problems with securing the area of course we left we left the Philippines before the enemy was totally defeated to move on
That's true.
As a matter of fact, our division, 1st Cavalry Division, wound up in southern Luzon in a camp preparing to go into the invasion of Japan.
Let's see, I guess it was August we came and assembled there, August of 45.
And then, of course, the atomic bomb was dropped in late August, or in August.
July and August, we assembled there.
And the war was over.
But we were immediately put on ships to go out to move into Yokohama and Tokyo, our division was, to secure the area for occupation.
Do you remember what you were feeling?
Shortly after we left, and after the surrender, I understand that there were some 4,000 Japanese troops surrendered very near where our division camp had been in the mountains above there.
We'd been fighting, but we really didn't realize there were that many troops in there.
So you're right.
We certainly hadn't wiped them out.
Do you remember your feelings?
In August, when you heard about the atomic bomb?
I sure do.
I thought it was a very courageous decision of President Truman to do this.
Of course, it was just the fact that we had the thing.
This was our first knowledge.
It was just almost unbelievable.
And then to hear the description of the effects of it was just beyond
because it was such a great leap from any measure of effectiveness that we'd ever known.
It was awe-inspiring, I would say.
And then, of course, we were, after the news of the first bomb, we just couldn't see how anyone could, any enemy could continue, and sure enough, it wasn't long until that was a fact, and

Everybody was relieved we didn't have to fight in Japan, because I think that would have been extremely... Having seen how the individual Japanese fought in the jungles, thousands of miles away from home, we could see some measure of the task ahead in defeating the Japanese on their home ground.
Now, since the dropping of the bomb, that maneuver by, or that action by Truman has caused a lot of

a lot of debate among different groups in America, people saying that, well, we shouldn't have done it, and other people saying that we should have, some saying it was against humanitarian law, whatever that is.
What was your opinion?
Oh, no question.
I've never felt that it was a mistake.
It's a shame that those people had to be sacrificed in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
But at the same time,
great multiples of Japanese lives in excess of that would have been lost, in my opinion, had we had to invade Japan.
Not to mention our losses, which I think President Truman was absolutely correct.
He was in a position to estimate.
He had estimates, I'm sure.
He was in a position to know.
In general, what the prospects were for the alternative invasion.
And I've never seen those figures.
I may have heard them at some time, but I'm sure that he couldn't in good conscience sacrifice that many American lives when he had the tool in his hand to prevent it.
No president could.
Do you remember where you were on B.J.
Day?
On V-J Day, I was, I don't remember the exact spot, but I was, you talking about the surrender day?
Yeah.
The actual surrender day of the ceremony.
Oh, I remember that very well.
I finally recall where I was when I first learned that the emperors said we were going to quit.
September the 1st?
It was early September.
September the 1st, I believe, or the 3rd.
Yes.
I was aboard a naval ship with the major elements in a convoy that consisted of the major elements of our 1st Cavalry Division sailing into Tokyo Bay Harbor.
And as a matter of fact, we had coming over our ship's radio
broadcast of General MacArthur's ceremony on the battleship Missouri just across the water there.
So you were in the bay, actually?
So we were coming in to land at the time they were actually signing that ceremony.
See, we'd been alerted to come on up.
Now, the 11th Airborne Division had flown elements into Yokohama ahead of us.
And when we arrived, they went on inland to another area.

and uh but yes that was a very dramatic moment for all of us who I'm sure all of these ships were receiving that broadcast and we were right there physically passing the Missouri at the time I bet you they really had the Missouri decked out well we couldn't see too well
But, of course, having seen later the movies of it, you know, the moving pictures of it, it was a tremendously dramatic moment of history.
Were there a lot of ships in the bay?
Yes, there were quite a number.
Of course, a lot of Navy in there at that time.
What were you on?
We were on a LST, my outfit was.
And we were very lightly equipped.
We left much of our heavier equipment back because they wanted us up there real fast and put us- I said LST, we were on a

an APA I'm sorry the LST was considered to be too slow and they came later with the rest of the division bringing the heavier equipment but we came all that whole convoy was APA or faster and so we moved very rapidly in there and then it was very interesting and a rather puzzling thing we went so hurriedly because all this occurred you know after the atomic bomb
was dropped and moved so rapidly.
I'm sure John MacArthur's headquarters had long had tentative plans for occupation of Japan, but it would have appeared before August of 1945 that that date was way in the future.
But when we loaded up the light elements of our division to go to Tokyo, Yokohama, after we got aboard, we were given
general plan and instructions for the occupation of the areas we were to be assigned once we got there.
Once we got there our division was told to go ashore in the dock areas of Yokohama and remain there and not move out of the dock area until further orders.
We knew that there were about a quarter million Japanese troops in this area at the time and

this surrender everyone was very hopeful of course that it would stick and that this meant everybody was going to surrender and that turned out of course to be the case so you had no incidents in which a troop would start shooting at Americans I know of none it was a remarkable thing I must say that I some others were so curious

I got in a jeep and I'll never forget this I got in a jeep with one of my officers I was commanding the 6th 1st People's Artillery Battalion at that time and a driver and just drove out a bit to just have a little bit of a look at the city and the Japanese had been instructed to continue their normal routine we came out at about quitting time in the afternoon
Masses of people were out on the street waiting for streetcars.
And as we would drive by, they would all turn their backs to us.
No kidding.
They'd turn their backs.
If they were in the bus and someone looked out and saw us, they'd turn their faces away.
And yet there was never a, this was their, I guess, a way of showing their embarrassment.

that is fascinating there was in those early days and thereafter there was never any really hostility it was an amazing experience I think the of course one thing he shows is the great discipline of the Japanese and all those troops in the months weeks and months later all those troops were disarmed
disbanded Japanese.
All that equipment gathered up.
That was a tremendous task.
You can't imagine what a task the occupation forces had initially in gathering up all this.
There were ammunition dumps with thousands of tons of ammunition.
What do you do with all that stuff?
What did you do?
Well, I think most of it went into the ocean.
airplanes on airfields.
How do you destroy them?
My unit, the direct support field artillery battalion, had the mission of putting out of action hundreds of aircraft on an airfield.
How'd you do it?
Well, we did it with, what do you call that stuff?
What we do is try to get into the engine with a, it's not an explosive, but it's a very hot burning material.

and you know melt enough of it to be inoperable and of course all kinds of weapons and things to be done so uh and what'd you do with the weapons well did you destroy them all or did you decide to just keep them in the armory or no the uh most of them were destroyed or dumped was there a fear that we should hurry up and destroy them before the Japanese well you can imagine Japan was uh
while they had a lot of troops in the islands that had challenged us down there, they still had their main forces at home.
And they had a quarter million troops right around Tokyo.
And you can imagine how urgent it seemed to our commanders, our senior commanders, Joe MacArthur and others, that this calm surrender is great, but we need to

gather the means of equipping these people and control it so uh we were very busy I can imagine of course uh we were in Yokohama just a few days and then uh entered Manila our division uh first guy division has the pride proud uh history of being the first in Manila the first in Tokyo and
and the first to reach the 38th parallel in Korea in the Korean War.
But going into Tokyo was quite a dramatic moment.
Tell me about that.
Well, of course, the whole division didn't march in.
The division commander with General MacArthur, Admiral Halsey, and a combat unit of the division
As I recall, it was a- So about how many men?
It seemed to me it was about 500 men, very small.
It was relatively, of course, the rest of the division is right there.
Made that initial entry and proceeded to the US Embassy and raised the American flag.
And I've got a picture here somewhere of that.
And you all marched.
And these troops, I was not among those troops, and these troops marched in vehicles.

into Tokyo and of course the Japanese were cooperative from the very beginning and this really signaled the commencement of the occupation then troops kept coming in of other divisions and being deployed to various parts of the country to occupy and again disarm the troops the Japanese troops and take control of the equipment and

Some very strange things happened because I mentioned earlier the occupation instructions, which included, for example, the usual things that historically have been done, like taking control of the government buildings and the post offices and the radio stations and the means of communication, in other words, and the airports.

seaports before we actually landed in Yokohama that day that I described I guess the first I think first September we were instructed to disregard the plan and orders for occupation go ashore and await further instructions that's a that's a rather
disturbing order when you're going ashore as one division with a piece of another division already there and 250,000 troops available to resist.
But the reason that was done was because of course the Japanese authorities had been so clear that they did intend to surrender and that they would do what they were instructed to do.

now how did you commence the surrender of these quarter of a million troops did you just pretty much line them up and tell them to hand how did how did this work many of them we would communicate basically it was a matter of communicating through their commanders and many of them actually disarmed themselves you know disarmed themselves disbanded without without there was such a vast number of them just sent home and we were just beginning to get in there you know we could not physically disarm
It would have taken God knows how long.
But so really, in many of those cases, the basic task for us was to get control of those arms that they laid down and weapons.
For example, this airfield at my unit took over a matter of days after we got in there.
I say days, probably a few weeks, as I recall.
They'd already mustered out.
The airmen just left this stuff.
Left a few people in charge, of course, caretakers, security guards.
But I never saw, by the way, I never saw any evidence of vandalism, theft, or cannibalizing equipment and so forth.
In other words, the Japanese people were... Keep in mind, the Japanese people were totally demoralized.
at the time we came in there.
We can't imagine.
I don't suppose any American can imagine, because we've never experienced it, what that bombing of nuclear weapons did to the population as a whole.
And of course, the facts of the results of those bombings spread like wildfire through the population, you know.
so they were not only disciplined and acceptable accepting the orders to surrender from their emperor but they were willing to surrender now what were the conditions like in Yokohama and Tokyo?
you mean the devastation?
yeah and the amount of food and supplies as you know

they're very densely populated areas and of course the first thing you see all kinds of people but the cities had been very seriously damaged because you know these fire raids have been going on for a long long time and just vast areas of both cities were just totally destroyed you wondered how the cities continued to function you know with their utilities and their

industries and their commerce but when I first went in there of course I wasn't too willing to even accept the Japanese as human beings because of the the kind of war they fought but of course you it doesn't take long to realize they are people are people wherever you find them in the world and most of them have the same basic

mores you know but my first admiration for the Japanese came from observing them under these circumstances pitching in and restoring their homes their buildings going on about their business working hard you never saw such industry

these terrible things that happened to them didn't stop them they just seemed to apply themselves absolutely completely to making a new world for themselves a new a new life I wasn't in Japan but well I left in January of 46 the soon after we came into Japan and
And, of course, it was evident that there were other units being brought in, of course, in various parts of the country to conduct this occupation duty.

And as it became absolutely clear that the Japanese were not going to resist the occupation and that we had control of their means of making war and of fighting locally, then, of course, our demobilization
planning began in the U.S. Army and Navy, Air Force.
So the so-called point system for rotation home was activated.
And some of the most difficult times of my overseas duty during World War II came in those few months between September and January.
Because all of a sudden, in November, all of my cohorts that I'd gone through the war with went home.
General William C. Chase was commanding the division, and he asked all the battalion and regimental commanders, brigade commanders, to remain past their rotation eligibility period.
All of us, of course, had points to go home.
until we could get the division remanned and retrained to some degree.
Well, of course, when he asked us to stay, we didn't know how long we were going to stay.
It was not entirely voluntary, I might add, but he put it on that basis.
And so we lost all of our people, just almost all of them suddenly.

people that came into Japan with us that remained were those few replacements that had come in to replace casualties and losses, which would have been, oh, I don't know, probably not more than 15% of the troops in my battalion.
And so, we got lower point men to replace those.
But many of these were what were left
in other divisions.
In other words, we started consolidating units, you might say.
But that first contingent that came in there to reman our units were a relatively high point, too, but not enough to go home.
And then they lowered the point criteria, and so we'd lose practically everybody again and get another refill.
It was a very, very turbulent period.

made it extremely difficult to do this was officers and men made it extremely difficult to do that occupation work that had to be done but of course eventually they settled down and I came home in January of 46.
How'd you get along and how'd your men get along with the Japanese people?
Was there any fraternization whatsoever?
Initially the instructions were there would be no fraternization and that was the case
But, of course, as time went on, as far as my time there, let's see, I was there nearly six months.
The fratrization, no fratrization policy was in.
But later, of course, it changed.
But we had very little access to the Japanese or contact with them, very little need to.
because most of our work was on military installations.
Very few of them were around.
What about time off, liberty for your men?
Was there a liberty schedule?
Did they ever get off?
Oh, yes.
It wasn't an easy or frequent thing, but the Army immediately started setting up rest and recreation centers, you know, in hotels around the country.
And I personally never took a day off, as I recall.
But that was our way of giving the men a break.
Send them to a fine hotel with good food and recreational facilities and good service, and just rest, do a little sightseeing.
That seemed to meet those immediate needs.
And of course, as time went on, after I left there,
I believe frequent trips in places like Hong Kong things like that troops could do but basically they had recreation centers fairly locally.
Now in 1945 when the war was over were you eager to go home?
Yes, I was.
The war was over.
My old buddies had gone home

I was really ready when that pole was lifted on me you bet did you entertain any thoughts of now getting out of the military and moving into banking well at this point I decided I was going to stay in the army and I guess the reason well uh I guess that uh
It gets in your blood.
That's one thing to say about it.
Matter of fact, when I came back to A&M after the war on the staff, I saw many of my classmates over the course of three years.

You know, they're coming back for football games or visits or whatever, and you'd be amazed how many of them who had, of course, served in the war and gotten out, whether they really would have done it or not, would say, gosh, I wish I'd stayed in the Army, which is simply evidence that it did get in their blood.

but by this time I felt that it was a fine profession and I guess it's fair to say that you don't really experience the complete dedication of men to their task and the effectiveness of men that'll match what you see in wartime oh yeah it's a matter of life and death and I don't know I guess you I kind of felt that
I'd kind of like to stay in an outfit that could demonstrate that.
That was a part of it.
So I never really, well, as I say, it just gets in your blood and you become a part of it.
Were you married at the time?
No, I was not.
I married some years after the war.
Married in 49.
So I just kind of, without having to debate it, decided I'd stay in.

I had the regular commission of course had been conscious that I was in the Army it wasn't a matter of staying in it was a matter of whether I got out or not whether I resigned or not not whether I'd be dismissed right because you had a regular commission a reserve commission so you came home in January of 1946 and became the staff officer of the field artillery school for the next six months
Yes.
Tell me about that.
That was very interesting.
You know, I told you I never had a bad job in the Army, but I hardly had a job at Fort Sill.
Sure, that only lasted for six months.
Because the fact was that the Army was demobilizing, and officers were arriving home from overseas faster than they could be placed in an assignment.
So I was at Fort Sill really just being given, you might say...

temporary jobs to do until they could find a permanent assignment for them which resulted in my being sent to Washington you might you see there after uh so you went to Washington in June of 46 but you only stayed there as the assistant G3 headquarters army ground forces for three months until October 46 yeah was that another situation in which they were waiting for you to are waiting to find a opening for a colonel no uh

I felt very fortunate to be assigned to that position and it was at a level that I'd never served at before and it was in Washington in the Pentagon but President Gib Gilchrist of Texas A&M came to Washington and said I want you to come to A&M.
He did.
And he said I'm up here to get you released from this job
That's the president, Ann Emerson?
Yes, indeed.
He came to Washington just to get you?
No, not just to get me, but he was in Washington on business, and he came to see me and told me that.
Of course, I had known him well as a cadet.
He was dean of the School of Engineering when I was at A&M.
And what he was doing, and he succeeded.
I agreed, and he succeeded in getting me released.

what he was doing was realizing that A&M's cadet corps had to be rebuilt because after my class was ordered to active duty on graduation and then the next classes were they just simply didn't wait for graduation they just take them out of the classes and draft them sure or order them to duty if they were to the officer school or many of them went to officer school of course
that were juniors or seniors.
I don't recall in detail how that happened.
But anyway, the Cadet Corps at A&M was basically of youngsters who were too young to be called or who had physical defects.
And it really must have been very disruptive, to say the least, of the Cadet Corps functioning and perpetuation.

President Gilchrist, with his staff, and I'm sure the military staff, attempted to find specific former students that could come in and join the military staff and help speed the rebuilding of that cadet corps, which was a very satisfying mission.
Well, let's talk about that because it lasted for three years, from October 46 until September 49.

you're a full colonel and you were made instructor of tactics I was a lieutenant colonel oh you were a lieutenant colonel yes well of course the primary duty there is the instructor's duty I was an instructor of field artillery in the military staff but the special duty you might say was the emphasis to guide that cadet corps
rebuilding properly.

And I think some of the things that were done that are of interest is that in addition to the old method of having the active duty military officers there act as tactical officers and advisors to the cadet commanders, we had some special things that we tried to do.
be very familiar now with the Ross Volunteer Organization.
The charter for the Ross Volunteers was rewritten to make it more a military and ceremonial unit and less a social unit.
It really functioned as much as a social unit in its earlier form.
And I think we can be very proud of the Ross Volunteers.
We always were, but I think they're
They're on a very fine and permanent basis.
Now, would you not agree?
And of course, we tried to get the matter of discipline and hazing in focus.
And of course, hazing is a, you have to let those cadet officers run their outfits.
There's no other way.
And the only influence that that staff can influence is through some leadership and guidance.
and gaining the confidence of those young people.
And so a special effort was made.
We had a very fine commandant there, General Guy S. Malloy, that many people remember.
He was succeeded by General Hayden S. Bolton.
They were both colonels at the time.
General Malloy later became a four-star general.
General Bolton became a two-star general.
General Bolton, I think, was a great favorite
former students because he went around talking to a lot of A&M clubs and he was a very colorful character anyway.
But for this critical period it was Colonel Malloy, General Malloy.
The President did direct some major changes in the policies regarding particularly hazing that affected the Corps.
Of course, we were still all military at this time.
And this was a very bitter pill for the cadet commanders.
They felt that not only had tradition as they knew it been disturbed, but that some of their authority had been taken away from them.
And we had a very serious situation there.
As a matter of fact, the cadet officers marched to President Gilchrist's residence.
and resigned en masse.
And Colonel Malloy, this was a very serious thing.
Absolutely.
After a few days, and it seemed that this... What was your opinion of this move?
Well, I'll describe that.
But Colonel Malloy, having, after a few days and just a day, seeing that this was serious and that they meant it and so forth,

I think we had an inspector general on his way from Washington very quickly and from a representative from Fort Sam Houston so of course Colonel Malloy instructed these young men to return and pick up their commissions and they didn't so what was at stake here all of those fellas
most of those fellows were under contract with the U.S. government, the U.S. Army, for advanced ROTC.
Well, the ultimate outcome of this could be that A&M would lose its ROTC unit.
It could.
Sure.
And looking at it in the most serious light.
So, of course, we were all very concerned about it.

I don't know that this really had much to do with it, but about three of us former student officers on duty with the military department got Colonel Malloy's concurrence to allow us to attempt to assemble these cadet officers and talk some straightforward about the gravity of the situation as far as the Army was concerned.
